au.edu.federation.caliko.visualisation

Class Camera

  • java.lang.Object
    • au.edu.federation.caliko.visualisation.Camera

  • public class Camera
extends Object
    Class to represent a 3D camera.

    Update: No longer need to reset the mouse cursor in the mouse movement callback - GLFW3 now uses a 'virtual' mode which hides the mouse cursor and does not limit its values, so instead of comparing the cursor location to the center of the screen we simply compare it to the last value.

    Version:
    0.5 - 07/01/2016
    Author:
    Al Lansley

      • handleMouseMove

        public void handleMouseMove(double mouseX,
                            double mouseY)
        Method to deal with mouse position changes.

        The pitch (up and down) and yaw (left and right) sensitivity of the camera can be modified via the setSensitivity method.

        Parameters:
        mouseX - The x location of the mouse cursor.
        mouseY - The y location of the mouse cursor.

      • move

        public void move(float deltaTime)
        Calculate which direction we need to move the camera and by what amount.

        If you are not calculating frame duration then you may want to pass it 1.0f divided by the refresh rate of the monitor in use.

        Parameters:
        deltaTime - The frame duration in milliseconds.

      • setMovementSpeed

        public void setMovementSpeed(float movementSpeed)
        Set the movement speed of the camera.

        If this is set to zero, then the camera cannot move.

        If a movement speed of less than zero is specified then an IllegalArgumentException is thrown.

        Parameters:
        movementSpeed - The speed which the camera moves forward/back/left/right.

      • setMouseLookSensitivity

        public void setMouseLookSensitivity(double pitchSensitivity,
                                    double yawSensitivity)
        Set the mouse look sensitivity of the camera.

        Setting a value of zero to the pitch sensitivity will mean the camera cannot look up and down. Setting a value of zero to the yaw sensitivity will mean the camera cannot look left and right.

        It is allowable to set negative values to the pitch and yaw sensitivity values, which will result in the mouse direction 'looking' in the opposite direction - for example, a negative pitch sensitivity will result in 'flight-simulator' controls.

        Parameters:
        pitchSensitivity - The pitch (up and down) sensitivity.
        yawSensitivity - The yaw (left and right) sensitivity.
